abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA) seeks
            an adequate management of waste disposal, particularly,
            medical, and biomedical wastes, derived from health
            treatments, specifically, those resulting from the incidence
            of HIV/AIDS. The EA first addresses the need to improve the
            institutional, legal, and regulatory framework concerning
            medical, and wastes disposal management, in an ecological,
            and sanitary manner. To this end, a regulatory management
            should be in place at health facilities, accompanied by the
            necessary budgetary resources to finance waste management,
            and support, and promote the use of recycled materials.
            Medical and hospital personnel, as well as private health
            operators, should be trained in waste management, while
            extensive sensitization, promotion, and public campaigns
            should inform populations on the risks associated with the
            non-compliance with waste management practices. Training
            programs, and strategies for sanitary collection operations
            should be made available, which should include the necessary
            transportation modes, and appropriate residues treatment
            systems, and processes for final disposal. It may include
            microwave, incineration, chemical disinfection, and disposal
            at landfills (following appropriate site selection), as each
            case may require.
